notesStmt.note: Reprints part of "Ten sermons tending chiefely to the fitting of men for the worth receiving of the Lords Supper" by John Dod and Robert Cleaver.
Running title reads: A dialogue of preparation to the Lords Supper.
Reproduction of original in the British Library, London, England.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A BRIEFE DIALOGVE, Concerning preparation for the worthy receiuing of the Lords SVPPER.
Taken, for the most part, out of the ten Sermons of Mr I. DOD, and Mr. R. CLEAVER, touching that Subiect.
LONDON Printed by I. B. for Roger Iackson, and are to be ≈øold at his ≈øhop neere FIeet Conduit, 1614.

div.head: A DIALOGVE of Preparation to the Lords SVPPER.

sp.speaker: An≈øwere.
sp.p: It is a Sacrament of the Mat. 26. 28 eternall Couenant, whereby through the v≈øe of bread and wine rightly admini≈øtred, and faithfully Ioh. 6. 27. 54. &c receiued, the ≈øoules of them that are ingrafted into Chri≈øt, are ≈øpiritually nouri≈øhed vnto eternall life.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What then is required of tho≈øe that will be pertakers of this heauenly foode at the Lords Table?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They mu≈øt b√©e prepared as m√©ete Mat. 22. 12 1 Cor. 11. 28. gue≈øts for ≈øuch a banquet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: For the better attaining to this preparation, how many things are there to be con≈øidered?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thr√©e: fir≈øt, what is to be done before the parting of it: ≈øecondly, what at it: thirdly, what after it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is it that mu≈øt be done before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There mu≈øt be, fir≈øt, an examination how fit w√©e are to receiue: ≈øecondly, a 1 Examination. premeditation of the benefits that wee are to receiue: thirdly, a faithfull and feruent prayer for Gods ble≈ø≈øing vpon our examination, premeditation and receiuing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Of what points are we to examine our ≈øelues?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, in generall, whether w√©e be of the number of the faithfull, and haue in vs the life of grace: for otherwi≈øe w√©e are vtterly vnfit to be partakers of the Lords Supper, which is appointed for foode to continue ≈øpirituall life where it is, and not to worke it where it is not: to b√©e for nouri≈øhment vnto Gods Children, but for the bane and de≈øtruction of dogs & ≈øwine, that dare pre≈øume to meddle with the ≈øame. Secondly, we mu≈øt examine our ≈øelues more particularly.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Concerning what matters?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Whether w√©e haue attained vnto a competent mea≈øure of Repentance, knowledge, faith, and loue: which if wee
can find in our ≈øelues, w√©e may re≈øolue our hearts in that point of generall examination, and conclude that w√©e are within the couenant of grace, and haue communion with Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, & therefore are in ≈øtate to be communicants at his Table.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How ≈øhould we trie our ≈øelues in the matter of Repentance?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: W√©e mu≈øt examine, fir≈øt, whether wee haue at any time carefully ≈øifted our 1 Repentance. hearts and behauior, to find out as many of our corruptions as po≈ø≈øibly we could. Secondly, whether we haue been, and are heartily ≈øorrowfull for the ≈øame. Thirdly, whether w√©e haue rightly confe≈ø≈øed them before the Lord, with an earne≈øt de≈øire of the pardon thereof. Fourthly, whether we purpo≈øe and re≈øolue for euer hereafter (through Gods gracious a≈ø≈øi≈øtance) to reforme both our hearts and wayes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is there any nece≈ø≈øity of that ≈øearching of our ≈øelues?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes verily: for otherwi≈øe we ≈øhall be found hiders of ≈øins, which hindreth all 1 Searching. See the Sermon on Pro. 28. 13. Doct. 1. Iob. 20. 12. true pro≈øperity, and argueth plainely that there is in vs a loue of iniquity, and abundance of hypocri≈øy, which will k√©ep vs from reaping benefit by the word or ≈øacrament.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhereby ≈øhould we try our ≈øelues to the intent that wee may come to a more full and particular ≈øight of our corruptions.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
By the Law of God, which is the true touch≈øtone: examining our ≈øelues by euery Commandement, that ≈øo w√©e may di≈øcerne, if not all, yet the mo≈øt part of the corruptions of our Soules, and errours of our liues: and for our more orderly proc√©eding herein, w√©e may v≈øe this direction following: wherein are ≈øet downe the chiefe heads of mo≈øt of the ≈øinnes again≈øt euery Commandement,
Sinnes again≈øt the fir≈øt Commandement.
1 AThei≈øme, which is, when men either If any doe de≈øire proofes of Scripture for the≈øe particular ≈øins mentioned, he may v≈øe the helpe of Mr Dods Booke on the commandements or of the True watc ‚Ä¢
where many of the≈øe are touched. thinke there is no God, or liue as if there were no God.
2 Idolatry: which is, the hauing of a fal≈øe god.
3 Ignorance, vncapablenes of knowledge, errors, and here≈øies.
4 Forgetfulne≈ø≈øe of good things, e≈øpecially of tho≈øe that mo≈øt concerne vs, and chiefly at that in≈øtant when w√©e ≈øhould make v≈øe of them. Secondly, remembring of euill things; e≈øpecially of tho≈øe that
mo≈øt corrupt vs: and chiefly then, when wee ≈øhould be mo≈øt fr√©e from the thought of them.
5 Vnwillingne≈ø≈øe vnto good things, principally to the be≈øt: readine≈ø≈øe vnto, and wilfulne≈ø≈øe in euill, e≈øpecially the wor≈øt. Secondly, impatience vnder cro≈ø≈øes.
6 Di≈øtru≈øt of Gods power, mercy, promi≈øes, and prouidence, whence carnall feares are wrought and cheri≈øhed, and the true feare of God is expelled & bani≈øhed.
7 Pre≈øumption vpon Gods mercy.
8 Carnall confidence in wit, learning, wealth ≈øtrength, friends, &c. thinking our ≈øelues the better, or more ≈øafe ≈øimply for them: whence ari≈øeth pride and ≈øecurity.
9 Too much loue of euill: as al≈øo of our ≈øelues, our friends, our plea≈øure, profit, credit, &c. Secondly, too little loue of God, and of goodne≈ø≈øe, of Gods ≈øeruants, and ≈øeruices.
10 Hatred of God and goodne≈ø≈øe. Secondly, want of hatred again≈øt our owne, and others ≈øinnes.
11 Abundance of worldly ≈øorrow, ≈øhame, and di≈øcontentment. Secondly, want of ≈øpirituall griefe, and indignation again≈øt our owne and others tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions.
Thirdly, not lamenting for the calamities of Gods people, priuate or publike.
12 Immoderate carnall mirth: too little ≈øpiritiuall ioy.
13 Hardnes of heart, benummednes of con≈øcience: or helli≈øh terrors and accu≈øations, proc√©eding from doing things either without, or again≈øt the rules of the Word.
Sinnes again≈øt the ≈øecond Commandement.
1 BA≈øe and vnwarranted conceits of God, as when we frame any Image of him in our minds.
2 Wor≈øhipping of Images.
3 Adoration of Angels or Saints, ob≈øeruing holy dayes in deuotion to them, ≈øwearing by them, &c.
4 Approbation of Idolatry by pre≈øence, ≈øp√©ech, ge≈øture, ≈øilence, k√©eping of ≈øuper≈øtitious relickes or monuments, k√©eping company with Idolaters, &c.
5 Neglect of any of Gods ordinances, as of preaching, hearing, reading, meditation, conference, the v≈øe of good bookes, and
of good company, of priuate and publike prayer, fa≈øting, making of vowes, &c.
6 Super≈øtitious fa≈øting, ra≈øh vowes, breach of lawfull vowes, abu≈øe of lots, &c.
7 Want of ≈øorrow for being borne of Idolatrous fore-fathers.
Sinnes again≈øt the third Commandement.
1 PRofe≈ø≈øion ioyned with prophanene≈ø≈øe, whereby Gods name is di≈øhonoured.
2 Abu≈øing of Gods word: fir≈øt, by fruitle≈ø≈øe ≈øpeaking of it: ≈øecondly, framing ie≈øts out of it, or again≈øt it: thirdly, maintaining of ≈øinne by it: fourthly, applying it to charming, &c.
3 Abu≈øing the names or titles of God: fir≈øt, by admiration, as by ≈øaying in our common talke, Oh Lord, Oh Ie≈øus, &c. Secondly, by cur≈øing, &c.
4 Swearing vainely, outragiou≈øly, and fal≈øely, &c.
5 Bla≈øpheming.
6 Taking a lawfull oath without due reuerence and con≈øideration.
7 Praying without faith, f√©eling, reuerence, feruency, not waiting for
an≈øwere. &c. A≈øking euill thinks: aiming more in our reque≈øts at the relieuing of our nece≈ø≈øity, then at the aduancement of Gods glory.
8 Hearing, reading, meditating, conferring, ≈øinging of p≈øalmes, and receiuing the Sacrament without preparation, attencion, renerence, delight, and profit.
9 Light pa≈ø≈øing ouer of Gods great workes, of creation, pre≈øeruation, redemption, as al≈øo of other his mercies & iudgements.
10 Abu≈øe of our Chri≈øtian liberty, to the hardening, in≈øuaring, peruerting, or iu≈øt grieuing of any
Sinnes again≈øt the fourth Commandement.
1 NEglect of peparation for the Saboth before it come, and of fiting our hearts for holy ≈øeruices when it is come.
2 Prophane ab≈øence from. or vnfruitfull pre≈øence at Gods ordinances.
3 Exce≈ø≈øiue eating and drinking, which cau≈øeth drou≈øine≈ø≈øe, & vnfitne≈ø≈øe for Gods wor≈øhip.
4 Doing any ordinary worke of our calling.
5 All recreations which di≈øtract.
6 Vaine and worldly ≈øp√©eches, and thoughts.
7 A ≈øecret de≈øire that the Sabbath were ouer.
8 Neglect of calling our ≈øelues, or others to a reckoning after holy excerci≈øes.
9 Giuing liberty to our ≈øelues in the night before the whole Sabbath bath be ended.
Sinnes again≈øt the fift Commandement.
Sinnes of all inferiours in re≈øpect of their ≈øuperiours.
1 VVAnt of reuerence inward, or outward: ≈øecondly, neglect of prayer: thirdly, of humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion.
Sinnes of all Superiours.
Fir≈øt want of loue: ≈øecondly failing in prayer: thirdly in giuing good example.
Sinnes of Children in re≈øpect of their Parents.
1 Di≈øobedience.
2 Murmuring at their Parents corrections, though vniu≈øt.
3 Contemning them for any defect of body or minde.
4 Vnthankfulne≈ø≈øe in not rel√©euing them, not ≈øtanding for their de≈øerued credit, &c.
Sinnes of parents.
1 Negligence in not in≈øtructing their children betime.
2 Not correcting them till it be too late, or doing it with vitterne≈ø≈øe without compa≈ø≈øion, in≈øtruction, and prayer.
3 Giuing them ill example.
4 Neglect of bringing them vp in ≈øome lawfull calling.
5 Not be≈øtowing them timely, and religiou≈øly in marriage.
6 Light behauiour before them, and too much familiarity with them, whereby they become vile in their eyes.
7 Louing beauty, or any outward parts more then Gods Image in them.
8 A ≈øinne peculiar in the mother is refu≈øing to nur≈øe them
Seruants ≈øinnes in re≈øpect of their Gouernours. The three fir≈øt ≈øins of Children may be in ≈øeruants, as al≈øo the≈øe that follow
1 Idlene≈ø≈øe in their calling.
2 Vnthriftines & vnfaithfulnes in dealing with their Ma≈øters goods & affaires.
3 Stealing, priuy defrauding of them.
4 Eye ≈øeruice.
Diuers ≈øins of Parents are found in Ma≈øters, as the≈øe that follow.
1 Vnadui≈øed entertainment of ≈øinfull ≈øeruants.
2 Not v≈øing religious exerci≈øes with them: not admoni≈øhing nor correcting them, or doing it in an ill manner: grieuing more when they faile in their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, then when they are ≈ølacke in Gods ≈øeruice.
3 Not recompencing their labours by giuing them a due reward when they are with them, & when they part from them.
4 Neglect of them in ≈øickne≈ø≈øe: vniu≈øt ≈øtopping of their wages for that time.
5 Not relieuing them (if they be able) in their age, who haue ≈øpent their youth in their ≈øeruice.
Sinnes of the wife in re≈øpect of her Husband.
1 Failing in reuerence, which appeareth in froward lookes, ≈øp√®eches, or behauiour.
2 Di≈øobedience in the ≈ømalle≈øt matters.
Sinnes of the Husband.
1 Not dwelling with his wife.
2 Neglect of edifying her by in≈øtruction and example.
3 Denying her comfortable maintenance, and imployment.
Snnes common to them both.
1 Want of loue.
2 Bewraying one anothers infirmities: di≈øcouering each others ≈øecrets.
3 Iealou≈øie. 4 Contention.
Sinnes of the people in regard of their Mini≈øters.
1 Di≈øobeying and oppo≈øing again≈øt their doctrine.
2 Denying them competent maintenance.
3 Not ≈øtanding for them when they are wronged.
Sinnes of Mini≈øters.
1 Slackne≈ø≈øe in preaching.
2 Vnprofitable or hurtfull teaching.
3 Giuing ill example.
Sinnes of Subiects.
1 Rebellion. 2. Refu≈øing to pay dues.
Sinnes of Magi≈øtrates.
1 Carele≈øne≈ø≈øe in e≈øtabli≈øhing and promoting true religion.
2 Of maintaining peace, and prouiding that Malefactors may b√©e puni≈øhed, and well doers be encouraged.
Sinnes of Inferiors in gifts or age.
1 No ‚Ä¢ acknowledging, nor reuerencing, nor imitating the graces of their ≈øuperiors.
2 ‚Ä¢ e≈øpi≈øing of the aged.
See the ≈øinnes of Superiors in gifts or age, in the very beginning of the fift Commandement.
Sinnes again≈øt the ≈øixt Commandement.
1 RA≈øh anger, enuy, hatred, & malice.
2 Brawling, reuiling, threatning, and prouoking of others.
3 Fighting.
4 Cruelty in puni≈øhing, oppre≈ø≈øion, &c.
5 Murthering of our≈øelues or others, or con≈øent thereto.
6 Immoderate worldly ≈øorrow: neglect of Phi≈øicke, or whole≈øome diet, and exerci≈øe in ≈øurfeting & drunkennes, all which are enemies to the health and life of man.
7 Cruelty to our own, or others ≈øoules.
Sinnes again≈øt the 7. Commandement
1 ADultery, fornication, ince≈øt, rape, Sodomie.
2 All wantonnes, ≈øecret or open, alone or with others.
3 Nocturnall pollutions, and lu≈øtfull dreames, &c.
4 Vnholy marriages, in regard of religion, age, n√©erenes of blood, want of parents con≈øent, &c.
2 Abu≈øe of the mariage bed, not ob≈øeruing the time of
naturall ≈øeparation
Leu. 28. 19.
≈øolemn humiliation
6 Nouri≈øhing of the cau≈øes and occa≈øions of wantonne≈ø≈øe, as impure lu≈øts, ≈øurfetting, drunkenne≈ø≈øe, idlenes, la≈øciuious apparrell, ≈øociety with la≈øciuious per≈øons, lewd bookes, ≈øongs or ≈øp√©eches: wnaton lookes, pictures, ≈øtage-playes, dauncing, dalliance, &c.
7 Wearing apparel contrary to our ≈øex.
8 Vnlawfull diuorce.
Sinnes of the eight Commandement.
1 COuetou≈ønes, and all de≈øire of our neighbours goods, albeit through feare or ≈øhame we cannot get them.
2 Church-robbing.
3 Robbing of our ≈øelues by wa≈øtfulne≈ø≈øe in diet, apparell, gaming, &c: by idlenes, vnadui≈øed ≈øureti≈øhip, nigardlines, &c.
4 Robbing of others, taking away the ≈ømalle≈øt things: fir≈øt by fraude: ≈øecondlyvncharitable inclo≈øure: thirdly, dealing wrongfully with the goods of the decea≈øed: fourthly, deceit in buying and ≈øelling:‚ñ™ fifthly, with-holding either things committed vnto vs, or things found lent, earned, or otherwi≈øe due.
5 Not making of re≈øtitution.
6 Coun≈øelling, or con≈øenting to others in theft.
Sinnes again≈øt the ninth Commandement.
1 FAl≈øe witne≈ø≈øe-bearing in publike or priuate, or con≈øent thereunto.
2 Rai≈øing, ≈øpreading abroad, or li≈øtening to fal≈øe reports of tale-bearers.
3 Ra≈øh ≈øu≈øpition‚ñ™ hard iudging, interpreting things in the wor≈øt ≈øen≈øe.
4 Aggrauating and di≈øcouering others infirmities without care of their credite, others edification, orour owne good.
5 Flattery.
6 Lying, though in ie≈øt, or to a good end.
7 Boa≈øting.
8 Iniurious charging of our ≈øelues to be hypocrites in time of temptation.
9 Want of care, of our owne, and others good name, that God might haue more glory.
The breach of the tenth Commandement: by
MVltitudes of euill thoughts and motions again≈øt our neighbours, and ≈øcarcity of ≈øuch as are good.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhen we haue attained to a particular ≈øight of our many and grieuous iniquities and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, what is further to be done for vs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We mu≈øt labor to bring our hearts Dan. 9. 9. 2 Godly ≈øorrow. See the SermoÃÑ on I≈øa. 1. Doct. 1. Iam. 4. 8, 9. Ier. 4. 14. Ioel. 2. 13. Zac. 12. 20. Chr. 13. 8 to true ≈øorrow & contrition for the ≈øame.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat v≈øe is there of that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is requi≈øite in diuers re≈øpects: it beeing a ≈øpeciall meanes to purge our ≈øoules from the pollution of ≈øinne, to moue the Lord to haue compa≈ø≈ø≈øion on vs, and plen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fully to poure downe his mercies vpon vs, without which, it is certaine there is no ≈øound repentance in vs, nor mercy to be expected from our God.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sith it is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øhew mee how it may be gotten?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, w√©e mu≈øt be≈ø√©ech the Lord, (from whom proc√©edeth euery good and perfect gift) to worke it in our hearts.
Secondly, w√©e mu≈øt v≈øe all good helpes to ≈øtirre vp our ≈øelues thereunto: as,

Fir≈øt, to call to minde the multitude, and grieuou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and offen≈øiuene≈ø≈øe of Nehem. 9 P≈øal. 51. our ≈øinnes, together with our long continuance therein: aggrauating them by euery circum≈øtance to make them more odious to our ≈øelues.
Secondly, to goe to the hou≈øe of mourning, Eccle≈ø. 7. and to make v≈øe of euery ≈øtroake of God, as well vpon others, as our ≈øelues.

Thirdly, not onely with patience to endure, but with earne≈øtnes to intreat, and with gladne≈ø≈øe to accept of the help of ≈øuch as haue broken hearts them≈øelues, and ≈øo are more able and ≈økilfull to pierce and wound the ≈øoules of others.

Fourthly, when by our owne ≈øifting, and others faithfull dealing; our hearts are touched with ≈øome remor≈øe, let vs ≈øeriou≈øly and throughly ponder vpon the infinite mercy of God the Father, in giuing his Sonne, and of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus in giuing
him≈øelfe for vs, who by rea≈øon of our ≈øins were deadly enemies vnto him: the con≈øideration whereof cannot but moue our hearts to relent, vnle≈ø≈øe they be altogether flinty, and hard as Adamant.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When our hearts are touched with inward griefe for our ≈øpeciall corruptions, what is to be done in the next place? 3 Confe≈ø≈øion. See the SermoÃÑ on Prou. 28. Doct. 2. 2 Ioh. 1. 9, 2 Sam. 24. 12.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: W√©e mu≈øt bring them in an holy confe≈ø≈øion before God.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What motiues are there to induce vs ≈øo to doe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Diuers: for fir≈øt, without this there is no promi≈øe of pardon of ≈øin, nor ind√©ed any godly ≈øorrow, or ≈øound repentance for ≈øinne.
Secondly, this is a ≈øoueraigne pre≈øeruatiue again≈øt relap≈øes, as may be ≈ø√©ene in Dauid, Peter, and Paul.
Thirdly, this is an effectuall meanes Dan. 9. 19. Neh. 1. 5, 6. to quicken our hearts vnto prayer.
Fourthly, hereby God is much glorified in his Truth, Mercy, and Iu≈øtice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Seeing this acknowledgement of ≈øin is ≈øo needfull, declare how it mu≈øt be performed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The≈øe rules mu≈øt be ob≈øerued therein. Fir≈øt that it proc√©ed from a good root, viz.
1 From an vtter hatred of ≈øinne: not from wearine≈ø≈øe vnder the Cro≈ø≈øe, as in Pharaoh, nor from ≈øome ≈øudden pa≈ø≈øion, as in Saul.
2 From hope of mercy: for if that b√©e 2 Sam. 14. 18. wanting, we ≈øhall neuer re≈øt on God for pardon.
Secondly, that it may be made in a good manner, viz.
1 Heartily and ≈øincerely, not coldly and hypocritically.
2 Particularly and with enumeration of our ≈øpeciall and mo≈øt beloued ≈øins, as in Ier. 31. 19. Paul and Ezra.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What will follow vpon ≈øuch a confe≈ø≈øion?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A de≈øire of reformation, and a full 4 Reformation. See the SermoÃÑ on Prou. 28. Doct. 3. Acts 19. 18 I≈øa 1. 16. purpo≈øe to abandon the allowance of euery infirmity, and the practi≈øe of euery gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinne.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How may this reformation be attained vnto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, w√©e mu≈øt con≈øtantly and carefully auoid all the occa≈øions of ≈øinne, and b√©e mo≈øt ≈øealous of our ≈øelues where w√©e are mo≈øt prone to be ouertaken.
Secondly, w√©e mu≈øt con≈øcionably and continually v≈øe all the meanes of goodnes.
Thirdly, when we are euertaken through infirmity, we mu≈øt pre≈øently and heartily lament our fall, and ≈øeeke a reconciliation.
Fourthly, if the≈øe meanes preuaile not, w√©e mu≈øt binde our ≈øelues by a ≈øolemne vow to ≈øtriue again≈øt our principall ≈øins, and mo≈øt dangerous corruptions.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: what other notes are there be≈øides the≈øe already ≈øpoken of, wherby we may be a≈ø≈øured that our repentance is ≈øound, & that our harts doe not deceiue vs therein?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
The≈øe following: Fir≈øt, if w√©e b√©e vniuer≈øall in our obedience de≈øiring to Notes of ≈øound repentance. P≈øal. 119‚ñ™ 6 See the SermoÃÑ on that place Doct. 2. P≈ø.
‚Ä¢ . 13, 14 Ioh. 31. 1. 1 Cor. 4. 3. practi≈øe or forbeare what≈øoeuer GOD would haue vs: not giuing a di≈øpen≈øation to our ≈øelues for the committing of any ≈øinne, or for the omitting of any du ‚Ä¢ y, but „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ manner of euill both in our ≈øelues and others.
Secondly, if we increa≈øe in goodne≈ø≈øe, neither waxing wor≈øe, nor ≈øtanding at a ≈øtay, but daily getting ground of our corruptions.

Thirdly, if in all our intents and actions w√©e looke vnto the Lord, as the ≈øearcher of our hearts, and the tryer & rewarder of our workes, not di≈øcouraging our ≈øelues what≈øoeuer men thinke, or ≈øpeake
of vs and our doings, ≈øo that God doe approue of vs and them: not contenting our ≈øelues with mens approbations when the te≈øtimony of God is not for vs.

Fourthly, if w√©e like be≈øt, and de≈øire mo≈øt that company in priuate, and that teaching in publike, where our ≈øpeciall corruptions ≈øhall be roundly and wi≈øely, and mercifully reproued & inueighed again≈øt, and the duties wherein we come ≈øhorte≈øt, mo≈øt earne≈øtly pre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øtood vpon: neither falling out with tho≈øe that admoni≈øh vs, nor denying, cloaking, excu≈øing or extenuating our faults.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What el≈øe is required in a worthy receiuer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
A competent mea≈øure of knowledge, ≈øo that he be able to di≈øcerne betweene the 2 Knowledge. elements, and the Lords body and blood: taking euery thing in it owne nature and kinde: not confounding the ≈øigne with the thing ≈øignified, nor putting no difference betw√©ene the Sacramentall and common bread, but v≈øing each of them in the manner apointed by Chri≈øt, and with ≈øuch reuerence as is due vnto them, & to that end for which they were ordained: namely, the commemoration of Chri≈øt
his death, and our n√©erer and fuller communion with him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat further examination mu≈øt we v≈øe before our communicating at the Lords Table?

sp.speaker: A:
sp.p: W√©e mu≈øt trie whether w√©e haue faith or not: without the which it is impo≈ø≈øible 3 Faith. Heb. 11. 6. Rom 14. 23. to plea≈øe God, and what≈øoeuer we doe is ≈øinne.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat then is to be beleeued concerning this particular ordinance?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That it is ordained of God not to Se the 2. SermoÃÑ on N ‚Ä¢ t. 14. Doct. 7. b√©e a ≈øigne to ≈øignifie and repre≈øent, but a ≈øeale al≈øo to confirme, and an in≈øtrument to exhibit Chri≈øt with all his merits vnto euery bel√©euer.

sp.speaker: Q‚ñ™
sp.p: VVhy is loue vnto men required in all faithfull receiuers.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe being de≈øtitute of that w√©e cannot be a≈ø≈øured of Gods loue vnto 4 Loue. vs, nor of our loue vnto him.
Secondly, w√©e cannot with any confidence Ioh. 3. expect at the Sacrament a generall acquittance from all our debts vnto God, except we in loue, can pa≈ø≈øe by ≈ømall offences in our brethren.

Thirdly, the Lords Supper is ordained as a ≈øeale of a mutuall fellow≈øhip, and Mat. 18. 35
communion of Gods people, as with their head Chri≈øt, ≈øo with one another.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhat rules are we to ob≈øerue in loue?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, if any indignity or iniury See the Sermon on I≈øai. 1 Doct. 1 Mat. 18. 35 Rom. 12. Mat. 5. haue b√©ene offered vs, w√©e mu≈øt forgiue, and forget the ≈øame, and ouercome euill with goodne≈ø≈øe: louing them that hate vs, and praying for them that ≈øpeake and practi≈øe euill again≈øt vs, at lea≈øt de≈øiring and ≈øtriuing ≈øo to doe.
Secondly, if w√©e haue done wrong vnto others, w√©e mu≈øt vndoe it againe: otherwi≈øe our ≈øacrifice and ≈øeruice cannot b√©e accepted.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But what if tho≈øe that wee haue wronged bee farre off, that wee cannot ≈øeeke vnto them: or will not yeeld to a reconciliation when it is ≈øought for?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: God will accept of our true and vnfained de≈øire in that behalfe, when a reconciliation is de≈øired, but occa≈øion denied, and if others will not be pacified towards vs, it is their fault and not ours, neither mu≈øt that k√©epe vs from the Sacrament.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: what is that Premeditation which mu≈øt be v≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is a ≈øerious con≈øideration of the 2 Premediatinu. benefits which we are to receiue by Chri≈øt Ie≈øus.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: what are tho≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
They ≈øet downe in the new couenant Eze 36. 21. Ier. 31. 31. (whereof the Lords Supper is a ≈øeale,) and they may be reduced to the≈øe heads.
1. Fr√©edome from all manner of euill what≈øoeuer, whether of ≈øinne or mi≈øery, in this life or in that which is to come:
2 The inioymeÃÑt of all good things:
1. In this World: and that,
1. For the inward man.
1. Perfect iu≈øtification.
2. True ≈øanctification.
2. For the outward man.
a good name, e≈øtate, ≈øafety, health, &c.
2. In the world to come.
all manner of happine≈ø≈øe. &c.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
Hauing thus examined our ≈øelues concerning our repentance, knowledge, faith, and loue, and v≈øed premeditation
of the benefits that are to be expected of all worthy receiuers, what remaineth further to be done by vs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: W√©e mu≈øt before our approaching 3 Prayer. to the Lords Table, earne≈øtly be≈ø√©ech his Maie≈øty to giue a ble≈ø≈øing to the≈øe our endeauours: and where w√©e haue come ≈øhort in fitting our ≈øelues, w√©e are to intreate him to pardon i ‚Ä¢ ; to accept of vs in the mediation of his deare Sonne, and to make a ≈øupply of all our wants, of his rich mercy and fr√©e grace.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But what if a man find that he commeth very ≈øhort of that examination, and preparation that is required; were he not better to be ab≈øent him≈øelfe from the Sacrament, till he be better fitted?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: In no wi≈øe: for if he be vpright hearted, See the 2. Sermon on 2 Ch. 30 Doct. 3 though neuer ≈øo weake, the Lord will accept of him. And if hee f√©ele his ≈øicknes to be grieuous and dangerous, h√©e hath the more n√©ed to ha≈øten to the Phi≈øition: neither is the ≈øtaying from Gods ordinance a meanes to better his e≈øtate, but rather to make him wor≈øe, and to pull Gods heauy iudgments vpon his ≈øoule & body. Num. 9.

p.hi: Thus much concerning the duties tending to preparatioÃÑ before our receiuing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How mu≈øt wee be di≈øpo≈øed in the pre≈øent act of receiuing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: W√©e mu≈øt pre≈øent our ≈øelues with reuerence be fore the Lord, ≈øetting our ≈øen≈øes How wee are to bee di≈øpo≈øed in the act of receiuing. I≈øai. 53. and our faith a works, and heed fully meditating vpon the≈øe fo ‚Ä¢ re things.

Fir≈øt, when we ≈øee the bread broken, and the wine poured out, w√©e mu≈øt con≈øider the bitter pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, who was wounded for our tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, and broken for our iniquities; who encountred with his Fathers wrath, and with Sathan, death, and hell: and for our ≈øakes in particular ≈øu≈øtained ≈øuch woefull terrors in his ≈øoule, and torments in his body, that h√©e cried out in the bitterne≈ø≈øe of his heart, My God, my God, why ha≈øt thou for≈øaken me? and at length, ≈øhedde forth his mo≈øt precious bloold for the pacifying of his Fathers di≈øplea≈øure, and the ≈øati≈øfying of his infinite iu≈øtice. And withall we ≈øhould ≈øeriou≈øly ponder vpon the inconceiueable loue of God the Father, in giuing his onely and well beloued Son, to ≈øuffer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch vn≈øpeakeable fortures for vs, who were cur≈øed Rebels again≈øt him: and thence b√©e drawne to thinke on the hainou≈øne≈ø≈øe and odiou≈øne≈ø≈øe of our ≈øinnes,
which ≈øo farre incen≈øed the Lords wrath & indignation, that nothing could quench the flame thereof, but onely the precious blood of his deare Sonne.

Secondly, when we ≈ø√©e the Mini≈øter di≈øtributing the bread and wine, w√©e are to con≈øider, that as tho≈øe outward elements are offered vnto vs by man: ≈øo Chri≈øt Ie≈øus with all his benefits is offered vnto vs by the ble≈ø≈øed Trinity.
Thirdly, that as we reach forth our naturall hand to receiue the bread and wine, w√©e mu≈øt withall reach forth the hand of faith to apprehend and lay holde on Chri≈øt.

Fourthly, in eating the berad and drinking the wine, w√©e mu≈øt apply Chri≈øt with all his merits particularly vnto our ≈øelues, and be a≈ø≈øured, that as that bread and wine are made the nouri≈øhment of our bodies: ≈øo Chri≈øt his body and blood are made the nouri≈øhment of our ≈øoules: And as certainely as the bread and wine are made one ≈øub≈øtance with vs, to ≈øtrengthen our bodies, and to refre≈øh our hearts, ≈øo ≈øurely Chri≈øt is made one with vs, and we with him, and then our ≈øoules ≈øhall b√©e ≈øtrengthened, and our hearts
≈øpiritually reuiued, either pre≈øently in the very act of receiuing, or afterwards in due time, when w√©e ≈øhall ≈øtand in mo≈øt n√©ede of comfort. And therefore in a≈ø≈øurance of faith we ≈øhould ≈øtir vp our hearts to expect all the forenamed benefits of remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, and ≈øanctification of our natures, together with the fruition of all outward ble≈ø≈øings, and the remouall of all hurtfull cro≈ø≈øes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: well were it for vs indeede, if we could look for the≈øe things to be be≈øtowed vpon vs: but the greatne≈ø≈øe and multitude of our ≈øinnes is ≈øuch, that we iu≈øtly feare they wil keep good things from vs.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This doubt ≈øhould not perplex See the Sermon on I≈øai. 1. Doct. 7. 1 Ioh. 1. 6. Eze. 36. 25 nor trouble vs, if w√©e be truely penitent for all our tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions: for Chri≈øt hath paid for many and great ≈øinnes, as well as for fewer & le≈ø≈øer: and through him the Lord is ready to pardon all, and all manner of iniquities, as well the greate≈øt of them, as the ≈ømalle≈øt, and if once our ≈øins b√©e done away, all the forenamed benefits doe of right belong to vs.

p.hi: Thus much concerning the meditations that are needful in the very act of receiuing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is to be done after our receiuing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fir≈øt, w√©e mu≈øt giue hearty thanks vnto the Lord for this ine≈øtimable benefite, 3 What to bee done after our receiuing. which w√©e haue receiued in being partakers of the Lords Supper.

Secondly, w√®e mu≈øt carefully marke how w√©e ≈øp√©ed, and what ≈øucce≈ø≈øe we find, and if the Lord aff ‚Ä¢ ord vs pre≈øent comfort, we mu≈øt be much more thankefull, and endeauor by all good meanes to nouri≈øh and cheri≈øh the ≈øame, and if w√©e mi≈ø≈øe of it for that time, w√©e mu≈øt notwith≈øtanding giue God the glory of his truth, in making good his Couenant and euery part thereof, and therefore with confidence and con≈øtancy waite and pray for the ble≈ø≈øing: re≈øoluing with our ≈øelues (euery one in his owne ≈øoule) that as ≈øure as God is true, and faithfull in his promi≈øes, w√©e ≈øhall in the fitte≈øt ≈øea≈øon reape fruit and profit by his ordinance, which in con≈øcience and obedience vnto him, w√©e haue b√©ene partakers of. In which regard euery particular bel√©euer may boldly ≈øpeake, in this, or the like manner vnto his owne ≈øoule: I haue with as great vprightne≈ø≈øe as I could, communicated at the Lords table,
and there receiued the ≈øeale of the euerla≈øting couenant of grace, and therefore it ≈øhall a≈ø≈øuredly be performed vnto me: and albeit my faith, and a≈ø≈øurance of Gods fauour b√©e but weake, it ≈øhall b√©e ≈øtrengthened, and what≈øoeuer Sathan, or mine owne deluded con≈øcience tell me, all mine iniquities are pardoned and couered, and I am at this very in≈øtant, as fr√©e from ≈øin in Gods account, as Adam was before P≈øal. 32. his fall, and as the Saints and Angels are now in heauen; yea, as Chri≈øt Ie≈øus him≈øelfe is, I being a member of his my≈øticall body.

And for ≈øanctification, though I b√©e tainted with much ignorance, with many errours, with bad affections and euill actions, yet the Lord according to his Couenant, will reforme all, and giue me a mind to know him, and his will, and a memory to hold fa≈øt what I know: h√©e will giue m√©e a heart to loue him, to feare him, and to obey his Commandements. I ≈øhall haue Chri≈øt his power to ≈øtrengthen and vphold m√©e, his wi≈ødome to in≈øtruct and direct m√©e, and his Spirit to worke all n√©edfull graces in m√©e, ≈øo that all the powers of hell ≈øhall neuer b√©e able to preuaile
again≈øt m√©e, much le≈ø≈øe ≈øhall the afflictions of this World be able to ≈øeparate m√©e from Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, I n√©ede not feare any euill: For all ≈øhall worke together for the be≈øt vnto m√©e, neither can I want any thing that is good, for God hauing giuen
Rom. 8. vs his Sonne, how ≈øhall hee not with him giue vs all things?

Thirdly, w√©e mu≈øt determine and endeauour to leade a new life, bringing forth the fruits of Repentance, Faith, & Loue, more aboundantly then in former times, as hauing renued our couenant with the Lord for that purpo≈øe: and therefore when we find any ≈øinfull motions ≈øtirring within vs, w√©e ≈øhould rea≈øon thus: Did I not at the Sacrament vowe and couenant with God to ≈øtriue again≈øt all manner of corruptions? and did I not receiue the ≈øeale of the couenant in a≈ø≈øurance that I ≈øhould haue power and ≈øtrength again≈øt them? Why then ≈øhould I y√©eld vnto them? why ≈øhould I be any longer in bondage vnto them? nay, I will not ≈øerue ≈øinne in the lu≈øts thereof, but will re≈øi≈øt it, and by the power of Chri≈øt I ≈øhall get victory ouer it: for the Lord hath ≈øaid that Rom. 6. 14. ≈øinne ≈øhall not haue dominion ouer vs.

So al≈øo when w√©e find wants and imperfections in our be≈øt ≈øeruices, as coldne≈ø≈øe in prayer, di≈øtractions in meditating, vnfruitfulne≈ø≈øe in hearing, deadne≈ø≈øe in ≈øinging of P≈øalmes, &c. As al≈øo impatiency, or faint-heartedne≈ø≈øe vnder cro≈ø≈øes, di≈øgraces, per≈øecutions, &c. Let vs thou rel√©eue our ≈øelues with the≈øe, or the like meditations: Was I not lately at the Lords Table, where I receiued a pledge of my ingrafting into Chri≈øt, who is the true Vi ‚Ä¢ e? and is there not in him ≈øufficient iuyce of all good graces to be deriued to euery branch that is in him: and is not the ≈øecond Adam as able to conuey his vertues into m√©e, as the fir≈øt Adam was to conuey his corruptions‚ñ™ why then ≈øhould I not ≈ø√©eke to him, in a≈ø≈øurance of obtaining ≈øtrength to doe and ≈øuffer what≈øoeuer h√©e will haue m√©e? yea, I will runne vnto him, and craue power and ability Iob. 15. from him, and a≈øking, I ≈øhall obtaine: for h√©e hath ≈øaid it, that will neuer fal≈øifie the lea≈øt part of his truth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: May it not then bee concluded, if immediatly vpon the receuiing of this SacrameÃÑt, we grow wor≈øe then we were before, that we came vnworthily therevnto?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes verily, if w√©e be ind√©ed wor≈øe, and not in our owne conceit onely, it is ≈øure that there was ≈øome ≈øinne or other vnrepented of lying vpon our con≈øciences, which cau≈øed Gods ordinance to be ineffectuall. Ind√©ed the worthie≈øt receiuers, in their owne imaginations, and through Sathans fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions, ≈ø√©eme vnto them≈øelues to be wor≈øe, (when in truth they are not ≈øo) becau≈øe they f√©ele their corruptions ≈øtirring more violently, and temptations ru≈øhing vpon them more fiercly then e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r before: but this is ≈øo farre from being an argument of vnworthy receiuing, that if they ≈øet them≈øelues to re≈øi≈øt this combate, there can be no more euident te≈øtimony of their worthy receiuing: for now that their ≈øinne hath had a deadly blow, it beginneth (like a mad bull in the ≈øame ca≈øe) to rage more furiou≈øly: and Sathan being di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of his holdes, plyeth his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe with new and fearefull a≈ø≈øaults; and therefore ≈øuch haue no cau≈øe at all to b√©e di≈ømayed, but rather very great cau≈øe to be comforted.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p:
But (will ≈øome ≈øay) what ≈øhall I thinke of my ≈øelfe in this matter, when I finde, that whereas I re≈øolued vpon new
obedience, I come ≈øtill farre ≈øhort of that which I am de≈øirous to performe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You n√©ed not di≈øcourage your heart for all this: the ≈øight of your imperfections argueth that your eyes are more inlightened then in former times, and that you haue gotten an humble and lowly conceit of your ≈øelfe, and your good d√©eds, which are things very plea≈øing vnto God: neither doth h√©e require ≈øuch ≈øtrict ob≈øeruation of the Commandements, as that w√©e See the Sermon on I≈øa. 1. Doct. 1. ≈øhould obey them in perfection, but onely that w√©e ≈øhould con≈øent in our hearts, and labour in our practi≈øe to y√©eld obedience thereunto: which if we can doe, the Lord See the Sermon on 2 Ch. 30 Doct 3. will graciou≈øly accept of vs, and of tho≈øe duties which w√©e performe, ≈ø√©eing that we fall not in the ≈øub≈øtance of his ≈øeruice, but onely in ≈øome circum≈øtances, and that full ≈øore again≈øt our wils.
